AloeVera.description: Aloe Vera is a succulent plant widely recognized for its thick, fleshy leaves that contain a gel rich in vitamins, minerals, amino acids, and antioxidants. Native to the Arabian Peninsula, it has been used for centuries in traditional medicine across various cultures. The plant thrives in arid conditions and is known for its soothing and healing properties, with approximately 200 active compounds including polysaccharides and enzymes.
AloeVera.how_to_use: Extract the gel from fresh leaves and apply directly to the skin for burns or wounds. For internal use, consume 1-2 tablespoons of aloe vera juice diluted in water daily, preferably after consulting a healthcare provider due to its potent laxative effect.

Amla.description: Amla, also known as Indian gooseberry, is a small, round fruit that grows on a deciduous tree native to India. Rich in Vitamin C (about 20 times more than an orange), it is a cornerstone of Ayurvedic medicine. The fruit, available in green or yellowish hues, contains polyphenols, flavonoids, and tannins, making it a powerful antioxidant with approximately 150-200 seeds per fruit.
medicinal_uses: Boosts immunity with high Vitamin C content
Promotes hair growth and prevents graying
Amla.how_to_use: Eat fresh amla fruit or drink 20-30 ml of amla juice daily. Alternatively, mix amla powder (1-2 teaspoons) with honey or water and consume on an empty stomach.

Amruta_Balli.description: Amruta Balli, commonly known as Giloy or Guduchi, is a climbing shrub found in India and Southeast Asia. Its heart-shaped leaves and woody stems are rich in alkaloids, glycosides, and steroids, contributing to its adaptogenic and immune-boosting properties. Traditionally used in Ayurveda, it thrives in tropical and subtropical climates.
Amruta_Balli.how_to_use: Boil 10-15 grams of dried stems in 200 ml of water, reduce to half, and drink as tea. Alternatively, take 500 mg of Giloy powder with honey twice daily.

Arali.description: Arali, or Oleander, is an evergreen shrub known for its beautiful but toxic flowers and leaves. Native to the Mediterranean and parts of Asia, it contains cardiac glycosides like oleandrin, making it a potent medicinal plant when used under strict supervision. It grows well in warm climates with well-drained soil.
medicinal_uses: Supports heart function as a cardiac tonic
Arali.how_to_use: Use only under expert guidance in controlled herbal preparations (e.g., diluted extracts) due to its toxicity. Avoid self-medication.

Ashoka.description: Ashoka is a small evergreen tree native to India, revered in Ayurvedic medicine for its bark and flowers. Rich in tannins, glycosides, and flavonoids, it is known for its uterine tonic properties and anti-inflammatory effects. The tree blooms with vibrant orange-red flowers and thrives in humid environments.
Ashoka.how_to_use: Prepare a decoction by boiling 10-20 grams of bark in 200 ml of water, reduce to half, and drink once daily. Can also be mixed with milk.

Ashwagandha.description: Ashwagandha, often called Indian Ginseng, is a small shrub with yellow flowers and red fruit, native to India and North Africa. Its roots contain withanolides, which provide adaptogenic, anti-stress, and rejuvenating effects. It has been used for over 3,000 years in Ayurveda and grows in dry regions.
Ashwagandha.how_to_use: Take 300-500 mg of root powder with warm milk or water before bed. Capsules (500 mg) are also available for convenience.

Avacado.description: Avocado is a nutrient-dense fruit from a tree native to Central and South America. Rich in monounsaturated fats, vitamins E and K, and antioxidants, it has a creamy texture and green flesh. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates and is prized for its heart-healthy properties.
Avacado.how_to_use: Eat the flesh raw in salads or smoothies. Apply mashed avocado as a face mask for skin benefits.

Bamboo.description: Bamboo is a fast-growing perennial grass native to Asia, known for its silica-rich shoots and leaves. Used in traditional medicine, it supports bone health and has anti-inflammatory properties. It grows in diverse climates and is harvested for its young shoots.
Bamboo.how_to_use: Boil young bamboo shoots or leaves in water for tea. Apply crushed leaves as a poultice for wounds.

Basale.description: Basale, or Malabar spinach, is a leafy green vine native to tropical Asia and Africa. Rich in iron, vitamins A and C, and antioxidants, it is used in culinary and medicinal contexts. The plant thrives in warm, humid conditions with its glossy, heart-shaped leaves.
medicinal_uses: Treats anemia with high iron content
Basale.how_to_use: Cook leaves as a vegetable or blend into a juice. Apply leaf paste topically for skin issues.

Betel.description: Betel is a vine native to Southeast Asia, known for its heart-shaped leaves with a spicy aroma. Containing phenols and essential oils, it is used in traditional medicine and as a stimulant. It grows in tropical climates and is often chewed with areca nut.
Betel.how_to_use: Chew fresh leaves or use in a mouth rinse. Apply leaf juice to wounds for healing.

Betel_Nut.description: Betel nut, from the areca palm native to the Pacific Islands and Southeast Asia, is a hard seed used as a stimulant. Rich in alkaloids, it has medicinal uses but is also known for potential health risks. The tree grows in tropical regions.
Betel_Nut.how_to_use: Chew small pieces with caution or use in controlled herbal remedies. Consult a professional.

Brahmi.description: Brahmi is a creeping herb found in wetlands across India, known for its small, succulent leaves. Rich in bacosides, it enhances brain function and is a staple in Ayurveda. It thrives in marshy areas and is harvested for its medicinal properties.
Brahmi.how_to_use: Take 300-500 mg of Brahmi powder with water or milk. Use as a tea from fresh leaves.

Castor.description: Castor is a plant native to Africa and India, known for its large, glossy leaves and toxic seeds that produce castor oil. The oil, rich in ricinoleic acid, has laxative and anti-inflammatory properties. It grows in warm climates.
Castor.how_to_use: Apply castor oil topically to skin or joints. Take 1-2 teaspoons orally with caution, under medical supervision.

Curry_Leaf.description: Curry leaf is an aromatic tree native to India, with small, shiny leaves used in cooking and medicine. Rich in carbohydrates, fiber, and antioxidants, it supports digestion and hair health. It thrives in subtropical climates.
Curry_Leaf.how_to_use: Add fresh leaves to cooking or brew 10-15 leaves in water for tea. Use oil for hair massage.

Doddapatre.description: Doddapatre, or Cuban oregano, is a succulent herb native to Africa and India, known for its thick, fuzzy leaves. Rich in essential oils and antioxidants, it is used for respiratory and digestive relief. It grows well in warm, sunny areas.
Doddapatre.how_to_use: Boil 5-10 leaves in water for tea or crush leaves for a topical poultice.

Ekka.description: Ekka is a weed-like herb native to India and Southeast Asia, with serrated leaves and small flowers. Rich in flavonoids and alkaloids, it is used for skin and wound care. It grows in disturbed soils and warm climates.
Ekka.how_to_use: Crush fresh leaves into a paste and apply to affected skin areas.

Ganike.description: Ganike, or Balloon Vine, is a climbing plant native to tropical regions, known for its balloon-like seed pods. Rich in saponins and flavonoids, it is used for joint and skin health. It grows in warm, humid environments.
Ganike.how_to_use: Boil leaves or seeds in water for tea or apply as a poultice to joints.

Gauva.description: Guava is a tropical fruit tree native to Central America, known for its green or pink flesh and high nutrient content. Rich in vitamin C, fiber, and antioxidants, it supports digestion and immunity. It thrives in warm climates.
Gauva.how_to_use: Eat fresh fruit or brew leaves into tea. Use leaf decoction as a mouthwash.

Geranium.description: Geranium is a flowering plant native to South Africa, known for its fragrant leaves and essential oil. Rich in geraniol and citronellol, it is used for skin care and emotional well-being. It grows in temperate climates.
Geranium.how_to_use: Use geranium essential oil in aromatherapy or dilute with a carrier oil for skin application.

Henna.description: Henna is a flowering shrub native to North Africa and South Asia, known for its leaves that produce a natural dye. Rich in lawsone, it is used for hair and skin care. It thrives in arid and semi-arid regions.
Henna.how_to_use: Make a paste from dried leaves and apply to hair or skin. Leave for 2-4 hours before rinsing.

Hibiscus.description: Hibiscus is a flowering plant native to East Asia, known for its large, colorful blooms. Rich in anthocyanins and vitamin C, it is used for blood pressure regulation and hair care. It grows in tropical and subtropical climates.
Hibiscus.how_to_use: Brew dried flowers into tea or use crushed petals in hair masks.

Honge.description: Honge, or Karanja, is a tree native to India and Southeast Asia, known for its seeds that yield oil. Rich in flavonoids and terpenoids, it is used for skin diseases and wound healing. It grows in coastal and riverine areas.
Honge.how_to_use: Apply Honge oil topically to skin. Use seed powder in herbal preparations under guidance.

Insulin.description: Insulin plant, or Spiral Flag, is a herb native to South America, known for its striped leaves. Rich in corosolic acid, it helps regulate blood sugar. It thrives in warm, sunny conditions and is popular in herbal medicine.
Insulin.how_to_use: Chew 1-2 fresh leaves daily or brew leaves into tea.

Jasmine.description: Jasmine is a fragrant flowering vine native to the Himalayas and China. Rich in essential oils like benzyl acetate, it is used for relaxation and skin care. It grows in temperate and subtropical regions.
Jasmine.how_to_use: Use jasmine essential oil in aromatherapy or brew flowers into tea.

Lemon.description: Lemon is a citrus fruit native to Northeast India, known for its acidic juice and high vitamin C content. Rich in citric acid and flavonoids, it supports immunity and digestion. It grows in warm climates worldwide.
Lemon.how_to_use: Squeeze juice into water or tea (1-2 tablespoons). Apply diluted juice to skin for brightening.

Lemon_grass.description: Lemongrass is a tall, perennial grass native to tropical regions like India and Southeast Asia. Rich in citral and geraniol, it is used for digestion and fever relief. It grows in warm, humid conditions.
Lemon_grass.how_to_use: Boil stalks in water for tea or use essential oil in aromatherapy.

Mango.description: Mango is a juicy fruit from a tree native to South Asia, known for its sweet flavor and vibrant color. Rich in vitamins A, C, and E, it supports immunity and digestion. It thrives in tropical climates.
Mango.how_to_use: Eat fresh fruit or brew dried leaves into tea. Apply pulp as a skin mask.

Mint.description: Mint is an aromatic herb native to Europe and Asia, known for its refreshing leaves. Rich in menthol and menthone, it aids digestion and relieves headaches. It grows in moist, shaded areas.
Mint.how_to_use: Brew fresh leaves into tea or chew leaves for breath freshening.

Nagadali.description: Nagadali, or Orange Jasmine, is a shrub native to Southeast Asia, known for its fragrant white flowers. Rich in alkaloids and flavonoids, it is used for pain relief and fever reduction. It grows in tropical climates.
Nagadali.how_to_use: Boil leaves in water for tea or apply crushed leaves as a poultice.

Neem.description: Neem is a tree native to India, known for its bitter leaves and seeds. Rich in azadirachtin and nimbin, it is a powerhouse for skin and dental care. It thrives in tropical and subtropical regions.
Neem.how_to_use: Chew fresh leaves or use neem oil for skin. Brew leaves for tea.

Nithyapushpa.description: Nithyapushpa, or Golden Dewdrop, is a shrub native to Central America, known for its purple flowers. Rich in flavonoids, it is used for wound healing and fever reduction. It grows in warm climates.
Nithyapushpa.how_to_use: Boil leaves or flowers in water for tea or apply as a paste to wounds.

Nooni.description: Nooni, or Noni, is a tree native to Southeast Asia and Australasia, known for its pungent fruit. Rich in proxeronine and antioxidants, it boosts immunity. It grows in coastal regions.
Nooni.how_to_use: Drink 30 ml of noni juice daily or use fruit pulp in recipes.

Pappaya.description: Papaya is a tropical fruit tree native to Central America, known for its orange flesh and enzyme-rich seeds. Rich in papain and vitamins A and C, it aids digestion and healing. It thrives in warm climates.
Pappaya.how_to_use: Eat ripe fruit or brew dried leaves into tea. Apply pulp to skin.

Pepper.description: Black pepper is a flowering vine native to India, known for its pungent berries. Rich in piperine, it enhances digestion and metabolism. It grows in tropical regions and is a key spice.
Pepper.how_to_use: Add ground pepper to food or brew with honey for tea.

Pomegranate.description: Pomegranate is a fruit-bearing shrub native to the Middle East, known for its juicy arils. Rich in punicalagins and anthocyanins, it supports heart health. It grows in Mediterranean and tropical climates.
Pomegranate.how_to_use: Drink 100 ml of juice daily or eat arils. Use peel in herbal teas.

Raktachandini.description: Raktachandini, or Leadwort, is a perennial shrub native to India, known for its red roots. Rich in plumbagin, it aids digestion and wound healing. It grows in warm, dry regions.
Raktachandini.how_to_use: Use 1-2 grams of root powder in water or apply root paste to wounds.

Rose.description: Rose is a flowering shrub native to Europe and Asia, known for its fragrant petals. Rich in vitamin C and phenolic compounds, it is used for skin care and relaxation. It grows in temperate climates.
Rose.how_to_use: Brew dried petals into tea or use rosewater as a skin toner.

Sapota.description: Sapota, or Chiku, is a tropical fruit tree native to Central America, known for its brown, sweet fruit. Rich in vitamins A and C, it boosts energy and digestion. It thrives in warm climates.
Sapota.how_to_use: Eat ripe fruit or brew seeds into tea. Apply pulp to skin.

Tulasi.description: Tulasi, or Holy Basil, is a sacred herb native to India, known for its green or purple leaves. Rich in eugenol and ursolic acid, it is an adaptogen used for respiratory health. It grows in tropical and subtropical regions.
Tulasi.how_to_use: Brew 5-10 fresh leaves into tea or chew leaves raw.

Wood_sorel.description: Wood sorrel is a small, clover-like herb native to Europe and Asia, known for its sour leaves. Rich in oxalic acid and vitamin C, it aids digestion and skin care. It grows in shady, moist areas.
Wood_sorel.how_to_use: Eat fresh leaves in moderation or brew into tea. Apply leaf juice to skin.
